bullets.text: Trump deems war with Venezuela unlikely but leaves option of land strikes open, elevating geopolitical risk in the Americas.
Retribution drive leaves D.C. U.S. Attorney’s Office in crisis, undermining prosecutorial independence and legal predictability for federal cases.
F.D.A. drug unit chief resigns over ‘toxic’ environment, signaling regulatory instability that could affect drug approvals, timelines, and biotech valuations.
OPEC+ plans one last output boost in December, then pauses hikes in Q1 to avert glut, supporting oil prices.
U.S. stocks extend November rally; sentiment tilts toward greed, raising correction risk if earnings or macro data disappoint.
Corporate profits remain robust despite labor-market worries, underpinning equities but complicating Fed’s growth-vs.-inflation trade-offs.
Nvidia emerges as earnings-season standout even pre-report; surging AI capex stokes debate over potential Big Tech investment bubble.
China rolling back rare-earth export curbs, easing supply-chain pressures for EVs and tech while signaling tactical détente with Washington.
LendingTree estimates Trump tariffs could add $40 billion to holiday shopping costs, pressuring consumers and margins.
Treasury says SNAP benefits could restart by Wednesday, partially offsetting consumer stress from shutdown-driven cuts.
Asia-Pacific markets mixed ahead of China PMI; Korea’s Kospi leads, highlighting sensitivity to Chinese demand signals.
Novo Nordisk’s outlook steadies as weight-loss market expands toward pills, rivals, and broader insurance coverage.
Quantum light breakthrough promises more efficient, scalable photonics, with implications for computing, sensing, and secure communications.
Artificial leaf converts air pollution into usable power, hinting at decentralized clean-energy and emissions-removal applications.
